Introduction

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the upper urinary tract.  VUR is the most common pediatric urologic condition and is associated with an increased risk for pyelonephritis and structural damage (eg, ureteral dilation, fibrosis) if untreated.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Urine flows from the ureters into the bladder through the ureterovesical junction (UVJ).  The ureters enter the bladder wall at an oblique angle.  During micturition, the detrusor muscle contracts to increase pressure within the bladder.  As the detrusor muscle contracts, it compresses the segment of the ureter that passes through the bladder wall (intravesical ureter), sealing the UVJ and preventing retrograde urine flow.  Therefore, VUR occurs when the UVJ is not properly sealed (

figure 1
), as follows:



  • Primary VUR (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  This occurs due to a congenitally shortened intravesical ureter, which enters the bladder wall at a more perpendicular angle.  Because of these anatomical differences, the UVJ cannot be completely sealed during micturition, allowing retrograde urine flow into the ureter.
  • Secondary VUR:  Less commonly, VUR occurs due to anatomic (eg, congenital posterior urethral valves (
    figure 2
    )) or functional (eg, neurogenic bladder) obstruction.  In these cases, higher intravesical pressure is required for micturition and overcomes detrusor muscle compression at the UVJ, allowing retrograde urine flow.


In general, the extent of retrograde urine flow determines the severity of the condition.  In patients with mild VUR, urine flows into the ureter only, and there is no associated structural damage.  Conversely, in patients with severe VUR, urine flows into the kidney and causes structural damage, including dilation of the renal pelvis (hydronephrosis) and blunting of the renal calyces.  In addition, if the urine is contaminated with bacteria, the bacteria can ascend into the upper urinary tract, leading to pyelonephritis.  Recurrent infection and associated inflammation can lead to fibrosis and chronic kidney disease.



The main risk factor for primary VUR is a family history of the condition, suggesting that the length of the intravesical ureter is primarily determined by genetics.  Any cause of urinary tract obstruction distal to the UVJ (eg, posterior urethral valve, neurogenic bladder) is a risk factor for secondary UVJ due to increased intravesical pressure during micturition.

Clinical presentation



VUR most commonly presents postnatally with a febrile urinary tract infection (UTI).  Older patients may have dysuria, frequency, urgency, and incontinence, in addition to fever.  Rarely, older patients with recurrent UTIs due to previously undiagnosed VUR have chronic kidney disease, which manifests clinically as secondary hypertension, proteinuria, and failure to thrive.



VUR can also present prenatally with hydronephrosis on prenatal ultrasonography (10%-40% of cases of prenatal hydronephrosis occur due to VUR), but postnatal imaging is required for diagnosis.

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected VUR (eg, age <2 with febrile UTI, any age with recurrent febrile UTIs, UTI with family history of genitourinary [GU] abnormalities), imaging of the GU tract is warranted.  For most patients, ultrasonography of the kidneys and bladder is initially performed to visualize the GU tract.  The presence of gross anatomic abnormalities (eg, duplicated or dilated ureters) on ultrasonography requires further evaluation, including voiding cystourethrography (VCUG).



VCUG involves catheterization to fill the bladder with radiopaque fluid, allowing visualization of urine flow within the urinary system during micturition (

image 1
).  Unlike ultrasonography, VCUG establishes the presence and severity of VUR by demonstrating retrograde urine flow during micturition.  Because the procedure is invasive, VCUG is performed only when certain criteria are met (eg, abnormal ultrasonography, hypertension).  Early detection of VUR is important because it can ameliorate the risk for recurrent pyelonephritis and chronic kidney disease.



In general, VUR severity is graded as follows (

figure 3
):



  • Mild (grades I and II) VUR involves reflux of urine into the ureter and kidneys with no associated renal damage.
  • Severe (grades III, VI, and V) VUR involves reflux of urine into the ureter and kidneys with renal damage (eg, dilated ureter, blunting of renal calyces, signs of renal papillary damage).

Management and prognosis



The management of VUR depends on the severity of the condition, as follows:



  • Mild VUR (grades I and II):  These patients are at relatively lower risk for recurrent pyelonephritis, and in general, prophylactic antibiotics are not warranted.  In mild cases, VUR can spontaneously resolve by age 5 as the patient grows and the anatomy of the UVJ changes.  Serial VCUG may be necessary to assess for resolution or progression, and prophylactic antibiotics should be initiated if patients with mild VUR develop recurrent pyelonephritis.
  • Severe VUR (grades III-V):  These patients are at increased risk for recurrent pyelonephritis due to retrograde flow of infected urine from the bladder to the ureters and kidneys.  Recurrent pyelonephritis can lead to fibrosis and chronic kidney disease, and therefore, prophylactic antibiotics are warranted.  Prophylactic antibiotics do not prevent reflux; however, the purpose is to sterilize the urine, mitigating the risk for recurrent pyelonephritis and subsequent fibrosis.  Cases of severe reflux and recurrent pyelonephritis despite prophylactic antibiotics may require surgical correction to prevent chronic kidney disease.


In addition to prophylactic antibiotics, other management strategies to prevent recurrent pyelonephritis include the following:



  • Prompt diagnosis (eg, screening ultrasonography in suspected cases)
  • Prompt treatment for UTIs
  • Emphasis of the importance of proper hygiene when toilet training (eg, wiping front to back to avoid contaminating the urethra with stool)

Summary



Vesicoureteral reflux (
